text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Russian newspapers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
SEVODNYA
- Russian Intelligence Services may be behind the confrontation between Iran and Western Europe.
- Despite the apparent conflict between Russia's gas monopoly Gazprom and the government, it is too early to talk about a weakening of Gazprom's positions.
- Andrei Vavilov, first deputy finance minister, who is now attending the EBRD annual meeting in London, is likely to resign soon to join a Russian commercial banks.
- One of Russia's biggest commercial banks, Vneshtorgbank, joined Institute of International Finance, Inc.
- The conflict between Russia's Central Bank and Federal Securities Commission over the national stock market is far from being resolved.
KOMMERSANT DAILY

- It is premature to be proud of Russia's moderate success in producing some goods, but there is no reason to be happy that other countries produce goods of even lower quality than Russia, says the paper, commenting on President Yeltsin's radio address.
- The sacking of Vitaly Artyukhov, head of the State Tax Service, is a stage in the power struggle between Prime Minister Viktor Cgernomyrdin and his first deputy Anatoly Chubais.
- Georgia is threatening not to ratify an agreement on Russian military bases in this former Soviet republic.
- Rem Vyakhirev, head of Gazprom, tried to reassure journalists that his company was not running into conflict with the government.
- Russia's main air carrier Aeroflot wants to strengthen its position on the domestic market.
- The conflict between the Central Bank of Russia and the Federal Securities Commission has a negative impact of the domestic stock market.
NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA
- The political activity of President Yeltsin after his recovery from serious heart and lung problems is often strange and erratic.
- President Yeltsin's visit to Germany is believed to help bringing Russia's and NATO's positions closer together.
ROSSIISKAYA GAZETA
- Last year commercial banks commited serious mismanagements of budget funds, said Alexander Smirnov, deputy finance minister and chief of the Federal Treasury Administration.
PRAVDA-5
- President Yeltsin's visit to Germany is political and will bring financial gambling in which Russia is likely to lose more than win.
MOSKOVSKY KOMSOMOLETS
- Russian producers do not need the president's or anybody else's appeals to patriotic feelings. They need proper conditions for to work.
-- Svetlana Kovaleva, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520
